No. 2, Consular Series Legation of the United States Monrovia Liberia Aug., 29, 1898
Owen L. W. Smith, to Hon. Thos. W. Cridler, Third Asst. Secretary, Wasington.
Subject: Acknowledgement of the reciept of your dispatch No. 5 of July 15, 1898, with Inclosure.
Synopsis: In reply to dispatch and inclosure, you are respectfully referred to my dispatch No. 21 of Aug, 11, 1898 with Inclosures.
Would not, at present, recommend a discontinuation of the Cape Coast Castle, Agency.
No. 2, Consular Series Legation of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia; Aug., 29, 1898.
Hon. Thos W. Cridler, Third Asst. Secretary, Wasington.

Sir:- I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your dispatch No 5. July 15, 1898, with Inclosure of a letter and petition of Pet. A. W. Reuner Esq. of Cape Coast Caslte, with thanks, for consideration & c. Your dispatch reached me, Aug, 27, 1898. In reply to which I mos repsectfully refer you to my dispatch No 21 Aug. 11 1898, to Department of State.
In reply to your instruction, that I report

Upon, the necessity of a further continuation of the Agency at Cape Coast Castle, would say, first, that the Gold Coast Colony, Africa, of which Area is the Capital, is a British possession; and according to Walker's Almanac of British possessions, in Africa, Cape Coast Castle has a population of 11,614 while Elmina, the house of the late George E. Eminsang, has a population of 10,530, hence from the population of the two cities, most of necessity, command a considerable commercial As to the matter of trade from the Gold Coast to the United States, it seems to have been greatly neglected. ANd until it shall have been properly worked up, I would probably be in recommending recommending

Recommending a discontinuation of the Agency. I would, therefore, the rather, recommend, that said agency, be continued until apportunity enables me to learn more of the place, or proper attention and arrangments by American merchants shall have been more fully made, in order to increase exports to, and exports from the United States.

As to the application of Pet. A. W. Reuner Esq. for the Consular Agency at Cape Coast Castle, I learned by inquiry that he is a Sierra Leonean, a man of much ability but for some cause was for some time disbarred from practice, but has subsequently been restored. Secondly, As it is now currently circulated, here, that peace has been declared, between

between the United States and Spain, it will doubtless give an opportunity for American vessels, to again with the Coasts of Africa, the better enabling us to decide upon the necessity of the agency. Thirdly: I will say as well as confidentially, that judging from as informed interview, believes the Secretary of State -- Monrovia, and myself on the 26, instant I am led to believe that it will soon be my privilege, as well as duty, to communicate to the department of State, Washington the expressed desire of the Liberian Government, to have the Government of the United States, to extend a protectorate over the Liberian Republic! And

And, in the event that the AMerican Government accedes to such a requestl as American gov do and manufactures, have even now, quite a demand, in Liberian markets; and on both the Liberian merchant and farmer, are very anxious to open up a market in America, for the exchange of their products; as an evidence of which I have already succeded in securing natural consignments of Liberian production, to New York, Baltimore, and Boston. notwithstanding, these products had to be shipped, by way of Liverpool owing to existing hostilities between the United States and Spain. Upon the cessation of

of these hostilities; and the return of peace; where shipping, by American cessels, can again, be resumed, without fear of being seized by enemies' ships; it is more than probable that such a protictorate would be the means of a more etended commerical between the United States and Liberia: thus necessitating not only, the retention of the Agency at Cape Coast Castle, but possible, the establishment of one at Accra, the Capitol of the Gold Coast Colony, with a population of 16, 276, as well as at Sinae, Harper, Cape Palmas, and the restoration of the Agency at Grand Bassa, Liberia. Awaiting further developments of affairs, between the two Governments, I
I do not, at this writing feel myslef, justified to recommend a discontinuation of the Cape Coast Castle Agency.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith
P.S. My dispatch No 21 Aug 11 1898 to Department of State should have been Consular Series, No 1 Owen L. W. Smith
